comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
Who's who in this photo?
Th officer (I'm going by the cut of his uniform) has Flying Corps wings above his campaign ribbons. campaign ribbons are also worn my the man to his right.
By the look of cap badges (a harp surmounted by a crown) and the dark uniforms they might be members of the RIC . The presence of a khaki clad officer also makes me think of RIC Auxiliaries, aka Black and Tans.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I'm assuming he's Auxiliary - those men were recruited from ex-WWI officers including the Royal Flying Corps. Most of the others seem to be Black and Tans. So many men (mostly WWI veterans) responded to British Government appeals for recruits to bolster R.I.C. (Royal Irish Constabulary) numbers, that there was a severe shortage of uniforms. Hence the Tans mostly ended up with khaki trousers and dark tops, either R.I.C. (dark green) or British police tunics (dark blue) - and hence the nickname...

comment._content: Nasty pieces of work the lot of them.  Great photo though.

comment.author: 34574252@N02
comment._content: Of particular interest is the fact that serving regular army Brigadier-General Frank Crozier [1879-1937] who was the C in C of the Auxiliaries resigned because when he tried to instil discipline, General Tudor, head of police operations, undermined his efforts to discipline some of his men for their conduct. This included reinstating [to different parts of Ireland] the ones dismissed by Crozier.

comment.author: 76216641@N03
comment._content: The cadet in dark uniform, leading with his elbow on the wall, right of the centre, is Section Leader of F Company John Charles Reynolds.
